title: Mutuelles de Santé Community Health Insurance
summary: Rwanda's community-based health insurance scheme achieved over 90% population coverage by 2010, starting from just 7% in 2003. Combined with 45,000 community health workers, the program contributed to dramatic reductions in child and maternal mortality.

keyData.label: Out-of-Pocket Health Spending
keyData.value: Fell from 28% to 18% of total health expenditure

keyData.label: Donor Funding Share
keyData.value: ~50% of health spending from external sources

content:
## Background

In the aftermath of the 1994 genocide, Rwanda's health system was in ruins. Health infrastructure had been destroyed, the majority of health professionals had been killed or fled, and the population carried enormous burdens of trauma, HIV/AIDS, and poverty-related illness. By the late 1990s, health indicators were among the worst in the world: under-5 mortality stood at 196 per 1,000 live births, maternal mortality was estimated at over 1,000 per 100,000 live births, and malaria was the leading cause of death.

User fees at health facilities, introduced under structural adjustment in the 1990s, represented a significant barrier to care-seeking. Studies showed that many Rwandans avoided formal health services entirely due to cost, relying instead on traditional medicine or simply going without care. The 1994 genocide had also devastated social networks that previously provided informal insurance against health shocks.

The concept of mutual health insurance (Mutuelles de Santé) emerged from pilot projects in three districts—Kabgayi, Byumba, and Kabutare—starting in 1999, supported by international NGOs and development partners. These pilots demonstrated that community-based prepayment schemes could increase health facility utilization and provide financial protection against health costs.

## The Intervention

Based on the pilot results, the Rwandan government adopted Mutuelles de Santé as national policy in 2004, aiming for universal coverage. The scheme was organized at the district level, with enrollment at the sector (sub-district) level. Members paid an annual premium—initially a flat rate of approximately 1,000 Rwandan francs ($2) per person—and received coverage for a defined package of services at health centers and district hospitals, with co-payments of approximately 10% of the cost.

A critical design feature was the tiered premium structure linked to Rwanda's Ubudehe poverty classification system, which categorized all households into wealth quintiles through community-based participatory assessments. The poorest households (Categories 1 and 2) had their premiums fully or partially subsidized by the government and donors, while wealthier households paid higher premiums. This cross-subsidy mechanism was essential for achieving near-universal coverage.

Simultaneously, Rwanda invested heavily in its community health worker (CHW) program. By 2009, over 45,000 CHWs were deployed—three per village—covering maternal health, child health, and general community health. CHWs were elected by their communities, received basic training, and served as the first point of contact for health services. They were equipped to treat childhood pneumonia, malaria, and diarrhea, and to identify danger signs requiring facility referral. Performance-based financing (PBF) was introduced in 2005 to incentivize both health facilities and CHWs, with payments tied to the quantity and quality of services delivered.

## Results & Evidence

The coverage expansion was extraordinary. From 7% enrollment in 2003, Mutuelles coverage rose to 27% in 2004, 73% in 2007, and 91% by 2010. Lu et al. (2012), in a landmark study published in *The Lancet*, analyzed the drivers of Rwanda's child mortality decline and found that the combined health system reforms—including Mutuelles, CHWs, and performance-based financing—were associated with a 60% reduction in under-5 mortality between 2000 and 2010. The study attributed the gains primarily to increased access to child health interventions, including malaria treatment, vaccination, and management of childhood illnesses.

Shimeles (2010), in an African Development Bank working paper, found that Mutuelles membership significantly increased the probability of utilizing health services and reduced catastrophic health expenditure. Facility-based deliveries rose from 28% in 2000 to 69% in 2010 and 91% by 2015, contributing to maternal mortality reduction. Rwanda was one of the few sub-Saharan African countries to meet Millennium Development Goals 4 (child mortality) and 5 (maternal mortality) by 2015.

Performance-based financing, evaluated by Basinga et al. (2011) in a randomized controlled trial published in *The Lancet*, showed significant positive effects on institutional deliveries and preventive care visits for children, though the effects on other indicators were more mixed.

## Challenges & Criticisms

Despite high reported enrollment figures, effective coverage—the proportion of the population with active, paid-up membership—was often lower than headline numbers suggested. Periodic re-enrollment drives were needed, and some households dropped out due to inability to pay premiums even at subsidized rates. Chemouni (2018), in *Social Science & Medicine*, argued that the rapid coverage expansion was achieved partly through coercive measures, including social pressure and administrative penalties for non-enrollment, raising questions about the voluntary nature of participation.

Financial sustainability remained a fundamental challenge. The scheme depended heavily on donor subsidies and government transfers to cover the premiums of the poorest. As the benefit package expanded and utilization increased, costs rose faster than revenue. The co-payment of 200 Rwandan francs per visit, while modest, still deterred the very poorest from seeking care. Additionally, the quality of services at health centers remained uneven, with drug stockouts and limited diagnostic capacity persisting in many facilities despite the insurance framework.

## Key Lessons

- **Community-based health insurance can achieve near-universal coverage in low-income settings**: Rwanda demonstrated that with political commitment, subsidies for the poor, and community-level organization, coverage can expand rapidly even in very poor countries.
- **Tiered premiums linked to poverty classification improve equity**: The Ubudehe-linked subsidy system ensured that the poorest could access insurance, though the classification system itself was imperfect.
- **Community health workers are a cost-effective delivery mechanism**: Rwanda's 45,000 CHWs extended the reach of the health system to the village level, enabling early treatment and referral that contributed to mortality reduction.
- **Performance-based financing can improve specific outputs**: PBF improved targeted health outputs but is not a substitute for adequate baseline funding and infrastructure.
- **Financial sustainability requires diversifying the revenue base**: Heavy dependence on donor subsidies creates vulnerability; long-term sustainability requires expanding the domestic tax base or developing mandatory social health insurance for the formal sector.
